You are correct. If you want to keep the SDD data, we will probably need to run custom SQL scripts. Could you help me better understand your use case? There might be another way to accomplish what you want. Why do you want to delete the FSAA data and only the FSAA data?

It's important to note that the Access Information Center uses the FSAA scan data as the scaffolding for all File Server resource data. So, if the FSAA data for a server is missing, then no other data for that File Server will be visible for that file server either.

Thank you,

Hello Joshua,

Got it, so it sounds like a lot of components actually depend on the FSAA
data being available. We have had issues with analyzing Broken Inheritance
and data for our workstations, the main issue being that the Broken
Inheritance analysis task would run endlessly, filing up the tempdb in the
process. The workaround was to modify the SQL Query for Broken Inheritance
and limit it to only run against our file server, and skip processing all
the FSAA data from around 300 workstations. You can find more details can
be found in ticket 00412142.

Naturally, we wanted to avoid having custom SQL queries in our
configurations, hence the idea to stop scanning FSAA on workstations and
delete any currently existing data. However, it does seem like this is not
the option, and we may need to continue having the custom SQL query.

Do you have information on the FSAC? Based on the licenses we currently
have are we entitled to run it?

Thanks,
Iurii

TextBody:
Hello Columbia University,

NetApp is supported but collections work differently than Windows File Servers. For NAS devices, the agent is installed on a proxy server. For NetApp, we configure an FPolicy on the NetApp side that collects the event data and sends it to the proxy server. Netwrix Activity Monitor's agent on the proxy receives, parses, and logs the event data. Netwrix Enterprise Auditor can then collect the data straight from the proxy server's logs or from a network archive. Theres a decent amount of flexibility in the deployment. Depending on the volume of activity and the specs of the application server, you can install the agent directly on the application server and forgo the proxy, although this is not recommended.

I'll close this ticket for now. Whenever you are ready to work on getting FSAC auditing up and running just open a new ticket. In the meantime, here are some Help Center articles for reference:

Requirements:
NetApp Data ONTAP 7-Mode Activity Auditing Configuration
NetApp Data ONTAP Cluster-Mode Activity Auditing Configuration

Administration
NetApp in Netwrix Activity Monitor
